Title:
Multiple-marker phylogeny and morphological evidence reveal
two new genera and species in Steccherinaceae (Polyporales,
Basidiomycota)
Keywords:
Molecular phylogeny; Polypores; Wood-inhabiting fungi;
Taxonomy
Abstract:
Two new poroid wood-inhabiting fungi, Coniferitrulla
densopora gen. & sp. nov. and Rudicula subglobosa gen. & sp.
nov., are proposed and described from East Asia based on ITS, nrLSU,
tef1 and rpb2 molecular phylogeny and morphological characteristics. C.
densopora is characterized by laterally stipitate basidiocarps with
flabelliform to semicircular pileus, hirtellous pileal surface with
appressed coarse hair and concentrically zones and sulcus, tiny pores, a
dimitic hyphal system, absence of cystidia, short clavate basidia and
thin-walled, smooth, cylindrical to allantoid basidiospores. R.
subglobosa is characterized by sessile or laterally stipitate
basidiocarps, velutinate to glabrous pileal surface with concentrically
zones and indistinctly sulcus, tiny pores, a dimitic hyphal system,
absence of cystidia, guttulate, short clavate to subglobose basidia and
thin-walled, broadly ellipsoid to subglobose basidiospores. Phylogenetic
analyses based on a four-marker dataset were performed with maximum
likelihood, maximum parsimony and Bayesian inference methods. The two
new genera formed independent clades with strong support in
Steccherinaceae. The discriminating characters of the two new genera and
species as well as allied genera are discussed.
